Hi Ken, 

Thanks for your reply. I agree  that step 2 is the more open. Int=
uitively, I prefer the interleaving approach as you do, so I'll try that fi=
rst. 

As to developing a controller modularly or monolithically,  I hadn't=
 considered the monolithic approach yet, and it bears thinking about. My in=
tuition (I have liottle more to go on right now) is that  keeping them sepa=
rate may promote a CPPN for scaleable morphologies (e.g., spiders with legs=
 of varying length) - that would be very nice to have. Also, a modular appr=
oach might adapt controllers more easily when body shapes change. On the ot=
her hand, it's just intuition and the same may be true for the monolithic a=
pproach. Hmmm....sounds like a little project right there. See if I can fin=
d a Masters student somewhere ;)

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Sta=
nley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Evert, sounds like a great project.  I thin=
k there is enough precedent for step 1 that it could be realistically achie=
ved.  Of course, step 2 is more speculative.
> 
> For step 1, my question i=
s whether it is necessary to regard the individual robots that make up the =
full organism as being separate for the purposes of evolving the controller=
?  That is, would it not work to simply regard it as a single whole and ign=
ore the individual separations?  That way you could just evolve one monolit=
hic controller for the assembly.
However, I can imagine that it might not b=
e possible to do that depending on your communication constraints.  In any =
case, HyperNEAT can represent it either way.  If the identity of each robot=
 matters, you can certainly input the location along the organism to the CP=
PN as additional information, and that could indeed be helpful.  
> 
> Step=
 2 (evolving the morphology) sounds very interesting butis a much more open=
 problem.  I think interleaving might be more effective than simply doing a=
 meta-search in which every potential morphology is evaluated through an en=
tire evolution run to find a controller for it.  That sounds very expensive=
.  After all, in nature both brain and body evolve together so presumably i=
t can happen here too.  
> 
> Also, the representation of the morphology (i=
.e. how it is translated from the CPPN output) will be very critical and de=
serves careful thought. 
> 
> ken
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "eve=
rtwh2004" <evert@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi all,
> > 
> > I am involved in a modul=
ar robotics project (www.symbrion.eu), where we are developing robots that =
can hook onto each other to create 'organisms' that consist of linked robot=
s. The robots can manipulate the link(s), e.g., to lift each other. Recentl=
y, Jeff Clune (hi Jeff) introduced me to hyperNEAT, and it looks like just =
the ticket to address two issues that we have to tackle. So here I am, exci=
ted newbie and all.
> > 
> > First, I want to try and use hyperNEAT to evol=
ve gaits for organisms with pre-defined shapes (e.g., spiders, snakes). The=
 idea is to develop a single genome that determines the weights for neural =
nets in each of the individual robots that make up the organism, so I would=
 expect to pass the coordinates of nodes within the individual NN, but also=
 about the location of the individual in the organism (possibly related to =
some central node or whatever).
> > 
> > The next step will be to use hyper=
NEAT's CPPNs to evolve morphologies for organisms. I'm thinking of a 3D gri=
d where the CPPN assigns some value to each cell which defines, according t=
o some threshold, whether a robot goes in that spot or not. The fitness of =
the CPPN would be the level of success in evolving a gait for the resulting=
 shape as described above. Another method of combining morphology and gait =
development would be to interleave them in some way (waves hands).
> > 
> >=
 So...does that sound like a good plan, are there any pointers to related w=
ork? Do's and don'ts? Expressions of interest, ridicule or awe?
> > 
> > TI=
A,
